This variety of nasturtium has attractive, variegated foliage and colorful flowers. It’s edible, with a peppery flavor, and offers antibacterial benefits, supporting the immune system and digestive health.

Also known as black seed or black cumin, Nigella has antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties. It’s traditionally used to boost the immune system and support respiratory and digestive health.
Known for its mood-boosting properties, St. John’s Wort is used to treat mild depression, anxiety, and insomnia. It also has anti-inflammatory effects and may support skin health.
This herb is commonly used for liver detoxification and protecting liver cells. It has antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties, supporting overall liver health and digestion.
Often used to prevent and treat colds, Echinacea is known for its immune-boosting properties. It also has anti-inflammatory and antioxidant effects, promoting overall wellness.
Known for its respiratory benefits, Hyssop helps ease coughing and asthma symptoms. It also has antibacterial properties, supporting digestive and immune health.
This herb is often used to treat respiratory issues like coughs and bronchitis. It has anti-inflammatory and soothing properties, making it beneficial for the respiratory system.
With attractive leaves, this herb is used in cooking and traditional medicine. It has antimicrobial properties, supports digestion, and can aid in relieving sore throats.
Famous for its use in body art, Henna also has medicinal uses. It has cooling properties, is used for skin conditions, and can help with hair care, promoting growth and reducing dandruff.
an adaptogen that helps the body cope with stress. It has antioxidant properties and may promote heart and immune health.

fragrant perennial herb used in potpourri, sachets, and beverages like May wine. It has traditional medicinal uses for digestive issues, anxiety, and fever relief, thanks to its coumarin content, which has mild sedative properties.

Spaced 15–30 cm apart in rows, matures in 45–60 days. About 29,000 plants/acre. Thrives in cool, moist conditions.
10 cm spacing, matures in 50–70 days. Approx. 145,000 plants/acre. Both root and tops are edible.

30x60 cm spacing, matures in 45–60 days. Up to 22,000 plants/acre. Promotes regrowth.
20x45 cm spacing, matures in 30–60 days. 80,000–100,000 plants/acre. Grows well in warm areas.
10–15x30 cm spacing, matures in 50–70 days. Approx. 145,000 plants/acre. Edible roots and greens.
5–10x20–30 cm spacing, matures in 30–45 days. Up to 200,000 plants/acre. Quick harvesting crop.
10–15x20–30 cm spacing, matures in 45–70 days. About 200,000 plants/acre. Used for leaves and seeds.
30x60 cm spacing, matures in 45–60 days. Up to 22,000 plants/acre. Cooked like spinach.

Spacing is 30–45 cm between plants, with 60–75 cm between rows. Plant population is about 20,000–25,000 per acre. Maturity time is around 2–3 months.
Spacing is 20–30 cm between plants, with 45–60 cm between rows. Plant population is approximately 25,000–30,000 per acre. Maturity time is about 1.5–2 months.
50x75 cm spacing, matures in 90–120 days. 10,000–12,000 plants/acre. Grown in cool seasons.

Grafted apple trees are preferred for their uniformity and better fruit quality. They start producing fruit in 2–3 years and are ideal for cooler highland regions. Plant spacing: 4–5 meters between trees, and 5–6 meters between rows.

The Hass variety is popular for export due to its creamy texture and long shelf life. It begins fruiting in 2–3 years with proper care. Plant spacing: 6–7 meters between trees, and 7–8 meters between rows.

These trees take longer (5–7 years) to bear fruit and may produce inconsistent quality, but they are hardy and suitable for subsistence farming. Plant spacing: 6–7 meters between trees, and 7–8 meters between rows.
Combines the hardiness of local varieties with the quality and faster maturity (2–3 years) of grafted trees. Plant spacing: 6–7 meters between trees, and 7–8 meters between rows.
Strawberries require well-drained soils and mature in 2–3 months. Suitable for both small gardens and commercial production. Plant spacing: 30 cm between plants, 60 cm between rows.
These types need trellising and mature within a year. They are productive and ideal for temperate regions. Plant spacing: 2–3 meters between plants, 3 meters between rows.
Similar to semi-erectile blackberries, this variety bears sweet fruit and thrives in rich, well-drained soil. Plant spacing: 2–3 meters between plants, 3 meters between rows.
Fast-growing and hardy, mulberries produce fruit in 1–2 years. They are drought-tolerant and can be grown in diverse conditions. Plant spacing: 3 meters between trees, 3–4 meters between rows.
Black raspberries require support and bear fruit within a year. Best grown in cool climates with fertile soil. Plant spacing: 45 cm between plants, 1 meter between rows.
Red raspberries are productive, sweet, and mature in 9–12 months. Regular pruning improves yields. Plant spacing: 45 cm between plants, 1 meter between rows.
A lesser-known raspberry relative, wine berries thrive in temperate zones and fruit within a year. Plant spacing: 45 cm between plants, 1 meter between rows.
Also known as sugar apple, it matures in 3–4 years and thrives in warm climates with moderate rainfall. Plant spacing: 4–5 meters between trees, 5–6 meters between rows.
Grapes require well-drained soils, full sun, and support structures. They begin bearing fruit in 2–3 years. Plant spacing: 2–3 meters between plants, 3–4 meters between rows.
Hardy and fast-growing, guavas mature in 2–3 years and bear fruit regularly with minimal care. Plant spacing: 4–5 meters between trees, 5–6 meters between rows.
A tropical fruit tree that matures in 3–5 years and produces large, nutritious fruits. Plant spacing: 6–8 meters between trees, 8 meters between rows.
This sweet lemon variety fruits in 6–18 months and is suitable for both containers and gardens. Plant spacing: 3–4 meters between trees, 4–5 meters between rows.
Hardy and easy to grow, local lemon trees bear fruit in 3–4 years and are highly aromatic. Plant spacing: 4–5 meters between trees, 5 meters between rows.
Limes grow well in sunny areas and start producing fruit in 2–3 years. They require well-drained soils. Plant spacing: 3–4 meters between trees, 4–5 meters between rows.
Loquats fruit in 2–3 years, producing small, sweet, and tangy fruits. Best grown in cool to warm climates. Plant spacing: 3–4 meters between trees, 4 meters between rows.
Grafted mangoes mature faster (2–3 years) and ensure fruit consistency and quality. Plant spacing: 8–10 meters between trees, 10 meters between rows.
Grafted orange trees produce uniform, sweet fruit within 2–3 years and perform best in warm climates. Plant spacing: 5–6 meters between trees, 6 meters between rows.
A high-yielding variety that starts fruiting in 8–10 months. It requires support and regular pruning. Plant spacing: 3–4 meters between plants, 4 meters between rows.
Sweet: Spacing is 3–4 meters between plants, with 4 meters between rows. Plant population is about 1,000–1,200 per acre. Maturity time is around 8–10 months.
Spacing is 3–4 meters between plants, with 4 meters between rows. Plant population is approximately 1,000–1,200 per acre. Maturity time is about 8–10 months.
Known for its resistance to disease and vigor, yellow passion fruit also matures in 8–10 months. Plant spacing: 3–4 meters between plants, 4 meters between rows.
Fast-growing and productive, pawpaw trees begin fruiting in 9–12 months and need well-drained soil. Plant spacing: 3–4 meters between trees, 5 meters between rows.
A sweet, seedless citrus variety that fruits in 2–3 years. Best suited for warm areas. Plant spacing: 3–4 meters between trees, 4–5 meters between rows.
Hardy and drought-resistant, pomegranates fruit in 2–3 years. They thrive in sunny, dry areas. Plant spacing: 4–5 meters between trees, 5 meters between rows.
Grafted trees bear fruit in 2–3 years and produce sweet, easy-to-peel fruits. Plant spacing: 3–4 meters between trees, 4 meters between rows.
Fast-maturing (12–18 months) and ideal for high-altitude areas. Needs staking and rich soil. Plant spacing: 2–3 meters between trees, 3 meters between rows.
Indigenous raspberry type maturing in 9–12 months. Thrives in fertile, moist conditions. Plant spacing: 45 cm between plants, 1 meter between rows.
A large passion fruit relative that matures in 12–18 months and thrives in tropical climates. Plant spacing: 3–4 meters between plants, 4 meters between rows.
Plums require chilling hours and mature in 3–5 years. Suitable for highlands and temperate zones. Plant spacing: 3–4 meters between trees, 4 meters between rows.
Produces fruit in 3–4 years and grows best in hot, humid regions. Known for its medicinal value. Plant spacing: 6–8 meters between trees, 8 meters between rows.
A small, fast-growing shrub that produces fruit in 4–6 months. Needs fertile, well-drained soil. Plant spacing: 1 meter between plants, 2 meters between rows.
Also known as Surinam cherry, this tropical shrub bears fruit in 2–3 years. Fruit is tart and aromatic. Plant spacing: 3 meters between trees, 4 meters between rows.
Small, sweet-tart berries produced within 6–8 months. Needs support and partial shade. Plant spacing: 1 meter between plants, 1.5 meters between rows.
Grafted pears bear fruit in 3–5 years. Best suited for temperate areas with well-drained soil. Plant spacing: 4–5 meters between trees, 5 meters between rows.
Known for its aromatic leaves used in cooking. Trees mature in 2–3 years and grow well in warm climates. Plant spacing: 3–4 meters between trees, 4 meters between rows.
Spacing is 5–6 meters between trees, with 6–7 meters between rows. Plant population is about 120–150 trees per acre. Maturity time is around 3–4 years.
Spacing is 3–4 meters between trees, with 4–5 meters between rows. Plant population is approximately 300–350 trees per acre. Maturity time is about 1–2 years.
spaced 2–3 meters between plants and 3–4 meters between rows, with a plant population of around 1,000–1,500 per acre. It typically matures and starts fruiting in 1–2 years with proper care.
